data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: I bought a food dehydrator several years ago & dry my own meals. A lot more variety than commercially made dehydrated meals.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Keep some food for emergencies, (peanut butter crackers, canned meat, noodles or backpack food) when you can't make the store, otherwise, buy when you need it. Carrying food, if you buy it along the way, doesn't make sense, in my opinion.
data.author: Dennis Peterson
Roberto Flores

data.text: Nuts. Al types. Snickers bars. Summer sausage and cheese. Crackers. Dehydrated meal packs.
data.author: Steven Etter

data.text: what meal packs
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: Mountian house is my favorite. Pasta primavera Chicken teriyaki Beef stroganoff Beef stew
data.author: Steven Etter

data.text: second to the mountain house chicken teriyaki.
data.author: Straffe Lycke

data.text: For road touring, I carry up to 3 days of food that I purchase from grocery stores. Usually box rice mixes, shells and cheese, perhaps a potato dish. I add either bag chicken (Starkist makes some really good ones) or Spam in pouches. For breakfast and lunch, I carry breakfast bars and granola bars plus supplement with stuff from convenience stores. I don‚Äôt eat lunch because I‚Äôve found it doesn‚Äôt sit well. For rugged touring (‚Äúcough‚Äù bikepacking ‚Äúcough‚Äù), I carry freeze dry because it‚Äôs lighter and easier. No need for pots and pans nor utensils. Not the best but there are some that are better than others. Lunch and breakfast are the same. I do make coffee every morning but only one cup per day.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: I‚Äôm more a credit card tourer and carry no food whatsoever üôÇ
data.author: Kieran David Barry

data.text: I‚Äôll eat road kill if I can have a couple cups of good coffee in the mornings.
data.author: Michael Armalavage

data.text: for coffee I use flavored Maxwell house instant and mix in hot chocolate powder. I prefer good real coffee but this works
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: Pack one one day, you can always stretch it but rarely do you not pass a food store in 2 days
data.author: Philip Yates

data.text: I do like to dehydrate my own food but nothing beats a Ramen-Bomb at the end of a long day of riding.
data.author: Scott Hawn

data.text: i bring a rifle and fishing gear to live off the land
data.author: Ronnie Cole

data.text: Pork schnitzel, mashed potatoes, t-bone steaks, lasagna, roast turkey.....not really. Rice is light and filling. Prepackaged tins of meat/ fish. Peanut butter and crackers for snacks. If going through towns eat other peoples food.
data.author: Mike Brooks

data.text: Beer, scotch
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: Instant oatmeal for bfast. Mtn house egg scramble w tortillas as a treat.

data.text: Those are really good, we brought a whole load back from NZ!! The Fish pie is awesome.
data.author: Malcolm Frost

data.text: I dehydrate and vacuum pack chillies and curries. Equipment pays for itself pretty quick and I know exactly what I'm eating (no stabilisers etc).
data.author: Beine√°n √ì hEid√≠n

data.text: Refried beans soft packs, tortillas, peanut butter and dried fruit trail mix
data.author: Glenn Tatum

data.text: Dehydrated soups for breakfasts, trailmix, peanut butter sandwiches for lunch, dehydrated suppers... the dehydrated are not "fancy" and granola bars. I add canned chickePineapple. breast and dehydrated peas and corn to suppers. Last but not least I am a type 1 diabetic so I also bring dehydrated fruit (typically pineapple). I am believer that the fuel in my personal tank should not be crapola (or deprived). So I try to make sure the dehydrated meals are not too bad (preservatives and sodium).
data.author: Andy Silber

data.text: When planning the first question I have is ready access to water (or not) can change plans substantially as I‚Äôm then considering weight and types of food more carefully. Also, even a convenience store vs. no restock options. If easily available then mix your own granola or muesli with spices, sweetener of choice (I bring honey) and nuts or dried fruit for breakfasts, bagels or hearty bread with PB, fruit and nuts, trail mix,‚Ä¶I haven‚Äôt had a freeze dried meal in 20+ years as I carry split lentils, onion, carrot, potato, ramen like noodles, and my own spice packet. About same weight and volume as freeze-dried, cook quickly, and taste much better. All cook in same thing you boil water in, too. Admittedly more pre-work than buying a pre-made kit, but you control taste, ingredients and have less waste to carry.
data.author: Jim Lee
